huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is rugged and vast bighorn sheep country and will be a very hard and physical hunt, be prepared.  2020 will be the first time a bighorn hunt has been offered on this subunit since the 1980’s.  With a limited number of permits, there should be little competition between hunters.  This unit encompasses some of the most beautiful scenery that Utah has to offer and most of it is very difficult to access.  Mandatory online harvest reporting is required.  Animal needs to be checked in at an office with a conservation officer or biologist, to plug the horns.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This unit is steep and rough with very little to no cell coverage. As in most bighorn sheep habitat, hunters should be in excellent physical condition prior to the hunt as most hunters end up walking dozens of miles and climbing thousands of feet prior to harvesting their ram. As with most bighorn sheep habitat, there is an abundance of cliffs. Be very careful scaling cliffs. It is advised that you bring extra rope to assist with getting through difficult ledges. A GPS unit is very handy on this unit to not only mark sheep and routes but also places where you can get through the ledges as they are relatively rare. Hunters can sometimes spend hours hiking along trying to find a way through the ledges and wasting time and energy. Bring plenty of water. It can be warm in November and there may be very little water on the unit.
A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to travel to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Weather conditions in November are variable on this unit.  Generally, plan on cold nights with mild days and little to no snow accumulation.  Most of the occupied bighorn sheep habitat occurs at lower elevations between 4200 and 6000 feet where snow generally doesn't accumulate.  Snow and bad weather is always possible in November.  Be cautious of flash flooding during rain storms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 33.3~125~90~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest: The majority of the bighorn sheep observed on this unit are found in cliff bands of mesa slopes, as well as on mesa tops or on the river edge. All of the large canyons along the Colorado River and their tributaries are all good locations to locate bighorn.

Scouting Tips: It is good to do pre-season scouting to learn the country. However, it is very hot on this unit during the summer months so plan accordingly. You will need a good pair of binoculars and a spotting scope. The unit is dry and rocky/cliffy. During the summer you will most likely see groups of ewes, lambs, and young rams. Some of the larger, harvestable rams will move in with these ewe groups in late October. Do not be alarmed if you don’t see many big rams in the summer, they will show up by late October. Hunting generally gets better the later you go. The peak of the rut tends to be the week of Thanksgiving. Find groups of ewes and lambs and often times a new ram will be with the ewe group each day as rams are moving a lot in November between ewe groups.
A way to cover lots of ground is to get to an area where you can see lots of mesa slopes and start glassing horizontally back and forth.

Behavior: The month of November is during the bighorn sheep rut. Rams are moving from group to group looking for ewes. Rams can also be observed butting heads. It is advised to occasionally stop and listen for the sound of butting heads it can be a good tool for locating sheep that are otherwise difficult to see. Sheep are generally active throughout the day in November but activity is highest in morning and evening. Bighorn sheep will not be as tied to water in November as it is generally more available that time of year if it has snowed. They tend to be found on the steep open cliffs and mesa tops and are occasionally feeding on the flat canyon bottoms or benches.

Ram vs Ewe: Both rams and ewes have horns. Ram horns are much larger than ewe horns and will form a curl. Many young rams will have a pronounced curl. The best way to recognize mature trophy class bighorn rams is to look for horn mass, particularly out near the tip of the horn. Younger rams that are 3 to 5 years old will have plenty of horn length but the horn tips are very thin. Mature rams 6 years and older tend to have thicker horns out near the tips, and thicker bases. Often times if you are close enough you can count horn rings on rams to get an approximate age.

Desert Bighorn Sheep rut: The bighorn rut runs during late October and extends through early December with the peak being around Thanksgiving.

Where to find Desert Bighorn Sheep: Focus on the steep mesa side slopes. Bighorns will generally be found on the rocky slopes, or open mesa tops, but occasionally can be seen in the grassy canyon bottoms. Sheep, Dark, Lost, Young’s, Lean-To, Bowdie and Gypsum canyons can all be good areas to check.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: After harvesting a bighorn sheep, you must bring the horns to a DWR office within 72 hours of leaving your hunting area. Checking in a bighorn sheep will fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement. If you received a bighorn sheep permit and did not hunt or did not harvest, you must complete your harvest survey online or by calling toll-free 1-800-221-0659 within 30 days of the season end date printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you being unable to apply for big game permits in subsequent years.

huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: San Juan County—Boundary begins at the Colorado River and SR-95; east and north along the Colorado River to the confluence with Indian Creek; southeast along Indian Creek to the Canyonlands National Park boundary; south along this boundary to SR-211 at Canyonlands National Park entrance; east and south on SR-211 to the Bridger Jack Road; south on this road to the North Cottonwood cutoff road down to North Cottonwood Creek; south on this creek to the USFS boundary line; west on the USFS boundary line to Calf Canyon then continuing south along the USFS boundary to the Woodenshoe Road; northwest on this road to the Fortknocker Canyon Road; northwest on this road to SR-95; northwest on SR-95 to the Colorado River. EXCLUDES ALL NATIONAL PARKS.
